text: today's recipe is kind of out of control
it's a twice baked potato casserole
that's made with raclette cheese which
is a delicious melty cheese obviously if
you can't get raclette you can use
another cheese like fontina Asiago or
Gruyere anything that appeals to you and
that you can get today I'm using
raclette I have baked five pounds of
potatoes and I'm scooping them out to
make the mash part these are Yukon Gold
potatoes which has a good ratio of
starch and a beautiful color and works
really well for this dish too these
scooped out potatoes add a third of a
cup of sour cream this is like big on
dairy I have to say four ounces of cream
cheese and the recipe calls for a total
of six ounces of cheese grated that's
about two and a half cups this is half
of that cheese that's getting mixed into
the mixture along with six tablespoons
of room-temperature butter that will
just make it melt much more quickly I'm
gonna mash this first before I start
adding my milk
add a half a cup of whole milk and then
mash it all up with some salt and pepper
kosher salt using 2 teaspoons and some
pepper this is going to be twice baked
like I mentioned so they've already
baked until they're tender and I have my
oven still at 375 degrees to bake them
their second time I'm gonna get this
into the baking dish and then I'll show
you what I'm gonna do with those skins
because I don't want to get rid of those
this is a two and a half quart baking
dish that has been buttered it's not
that easy to hold five pounds of
potatoes in one hand and talk and smile
god this is delicious already but just
you wait it gets better
spread it out evenly and just set that
aside for a sec grate some cheese this
is the remainder of that six ounces of
cheese to go on top so this remainder of
the raclette should be another like one
and a quarter cups and that goes on top
of the casserole
I must still get all melty as it bakes
now for the skins you're going to cut
those up into one and a half inch wide
strips and they are going to roast
alongside your casserole one sec and I'm
gonna go get my other ingredients and
then I'll show you what I'm gonna do
with these I have some olive oil some
sage and some chopped garlic so you're
gonna take your potato skins put them
onto a rimmed baking sheet drizzle with
a third of a cup of olive oil you can do
this right on the baking sheet or you
can do it in the bowl it's up to you
give it a toss the this is the fun part
about this because these are gonna roast
right alongside the rest of the
casserole and they get all crispy and
crunchy and then you can eat them on the
side or you can serve them on top eight
large sage leaves that have been
coarsely chopped couple cloves garlic
these are kind of bangs don't use it all
and then season with some salt
at itas spread them out so they're in as
much of a single-layer as possible
and then these both go into the oven the
casserole will go on the top rack and
the potato skins will go on the bottom
rack and you cook it until this is hot
and bubbling and these are crisp that'll
take about 25 to 30 minutes when it
comes out you probably gonna want to let
it cool just a little bit because it is
quite molten inside you can sprinkle it
with some chives you can top with some
of these potato skins you can just put
them on top there's gonna be more potato
skins than you need to top the casserole
which is totally fine because they're
delicious to eat on their own a really
delicious snack to save those all for
yourself believe me that's it it's

oh so delicious
hmm you know I couldn't believe it so
